As the 2009 bipartisan Congressional Commission on the Strategic Posture of the United States stated: ‚ÄòPotential aggressors should have to worry about the possibility that the United States might respond by overwhelming means at a time and in a manner of its choosing.
With Russia and China increasingly attempting to intimidate their neighbors ‚Äì some of whom are U.S. allies ‚Äì this is the wrong message to send. It betrays a na√Øve and disturbed world view.

Presidents from both parties, including the Obama administration, have rejected a no-first-use policy because it erodes deterrence, undermines allied confidence in U.S. security guarantees and risks emboldening potential adversaries. https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-first-use-nuclear-policyproposal-assailed-by-u-s-cabinet-officials-allies-1471042014¬†‚Ä¶
Calculated ambiguity has long been an element of U.S. nuclear declaratory policy.

During this Congress, I‚Äôm looking forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle on this key priority and continuing our work in providing for a strong national defense.

While @US_Stratcom is located in Sarpy County, NE, it is a national asset with a global mission ‚Äì over 180,000 Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen, Marines, and civilians are working every day around the world in support of the command‚Äôs mission. #Service

That means any delay or any error, could put at risk our ability to field an effective nuclear deterrent in the future, and we cannot allow that to happen. In the face of growing threats, our deterrent must remain strong.
As a result of decisions to delay and defer funding, there is no margin for error in the schedule.
The command and control networks that our nuclear forces rely on are also in need of replacement, as is the scientific #infrastructure that maintains our stockpile of aging warheads.
As our nuclear deterrent becomes more important to our nation‚Äôs defense, the need for nuclear modernization only grows. This conclusion is echoed by the administration‚Äôs #NuclearPostureReview.
Meanwhile, our warheads and delivery systems age toward obsolescence, as does the #infrastructure that maintains our deterrent.

With #Russia and #China increasingly seeking to challenge US interests and reshape the geopolitical landscape in their favor, the unique role our nuclear forces play in deterring conflict & preventing war is becoming increasingly important.
As part of the effort to ensure our military is prepared for new threats, we must continue modernizing our #nuclearforces.
I‚Äôm entering my 7th year on the Senate Armed Services Committee where we‚Äôve continued the committee‚Äôs long-standing, bipartisan tradition of working to strengthen our #military.
